awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Microbes and Microplastics:  Microbial Adaptations during the Anthropocene
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Plastic pollution within global marine systems has created artificial surface environments for microorganisms to grow and establish unknown ecological roles. Some microbes have the ability to degrade microplastic polymers in the environment, but it remains unclear whether certain genes that allow this degradation result normally from evolution. Understanding how these potential adaptations microbes undergo to degrade human-made plastics is critical for better understanding the impacts plastics have on the environment. Training of this fellow will further help broaden participation by integrating research activities and instructional workshops aimed at undergraduate students within Stony Brook University’s Women in Science and Engineering (WISE) and Institute for STEM Education (I-STEM) programs.

	This project will test the hypothesis that microbial microplastic degradation effectiveness is controlled by microplastic polymer type and unveil the core genomic adaptations that might contribute to alteration of the global carbon cycle. Deployment of sampling arrays containing clean microplastic debris of common polymer types (polypropylene, polystyrene, polyethylene, and polycarbonate) along a contaminant gradient in the Long Island Sound will promote natural microbial colonization for hypothesis testing. Determining rates of microplastic degradation according to polymer type in a laboratory setting will further complement field sample analysis by linking microbial identities to function via predictive models of plastic-degraders’ impact on global budgets. Integrative training in advanced molecular techniques (i.e., stable isotope probing, fluorescence in-situ hybridization of cells, and Raman microspectroscopy) and advanced genomic techniques (i.e., metapangenomics and metatranscriptomics) will advance the fellow’s early academic career development and increase understanding of the impacts of microbial microplastic degradation across all three domains of life. Hands-on exposure to these advanced techniques within Stony Brook University’s WISE and I-STEM programs will most importantly lay the foundation for young aspiring minds to pursue career paths in global change biology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This fellowship project served to improve understanding and raise public awareness regarding the impact of human activities on microbial life. The project investigated how marine microbes have adapted to the large input of plastic pollution into the global ocean by analyzing natural microbial colonization of many different plastic polymer types within the highly urbanized waterways surrounding New York City and Long Island, New York. It was hypothesized that microbes living in urban coastal systems may have increased adaptations for interacting with and utilizing plastic debris due to increased exposure to plastic pollution compared to less urbanized systems. Our diverse team of project participants including high school and undergraduate students deployed microplastics of six different plastic polymer types for eight weeks at four strategic study sites within this urban coastal ecosystem. The goal was to understand whether there was a difference between polymer types and between study sites in terms of microbial members present and their respective gene content. The project also tested microbial colonization of glass beads deployed alongside the microplastics, and of the microbial characteristics of surrounding seawater as two forms of controls for project experiments. Upon retrieval of our samples, DNA and RNA was extracted to reveal “who is there?”, “who is active?”, and “do their gene contents show signs of adaptation towards plastic pollution?”. After retrieval, laboratory cultures were used to learn more about differences in microbial communities among each plastic polymer type. Cultures were not fed any source of organic carbon to promote the growth of microbes that may utilize plastic itself as a primary carbon source. Finally, pure cultures of a known plastic-degrading microbe were grown using polyethylene, which was traceable using a stable isotope (13C) as a sole source of carbon. A technique called Raman microscpectroscopy was used to measure any incorporation of 13C into individual cellular biomass.

 

Results from these experiments showed that microbes known to degrade hydrocarbons were found in greater abundance on microplastics deployed closer to New York City. This suggests that geographic regions with high rates of plastic pollution may harbor more microbes that are adapted and evolved to use hydrocarbon degradation pathways on plastic debris. These hydrocarbon degraders were also found in greater abundance on polyethylene and polyvinyl chloride compared to other plastic polymers. This suggests that different plastic polymer types may be more bioavailable and biodegradable than others in marine environments. Laboratory culture results showed that colonized plastic can sustain higher microbial abundance than glass bead controls in controlled laboratory conditions for long time periods to potentially select for and study plastic-specialized microorganisms. Stable isotope and Raman microspectroscopy experiments with plastic-fed pure cultures of bacteria showed signs of polyethylene incorporation into cellular biomass, but additional experimental trials are needed to confirm and estimate plastic degradation rates. However, several new species of hydrocarbon-degrading bacteria were discovered from our DNA sequencing results and provide insight into potential adaptations toward plastic pollution in urbanized coastal systems. These potential adaptations were highlighted by groups of “core genes” that were shared between these novel species colonizing plastic in this geographic region. We also identified community-wide functional genes that were unique to plastic compared to glass bead controls. Additional analysis of global ocean metagenomic surveys provided preliminary evidence for the potential global distribution and ubiquity of the novel hydrocarbon-degrading bacterial species recovered from plastic deployed within New York City waterways in this study. These results provide a greater understanding for how highly urbanized coastal systems can provide a mechanism for microbial adaptation and evolution that could potentially disperse novel phenotypes across the global ocean. Overall, this study has shown that microorganisms have adapted to utilize man-made plastic substrates in the environment and fulfill vacant roles within the ecosystem in a short geologic time period (the Anthropocene).

 

This project provided one-on-one training and mentoring for three high school students, three undergraduate students, and one graduate student from diverse and underrepresented groups. This project also served as a platform for the development of a 4-part workshop series for local Long Island high school students in collaboration with the Institute for STEM Education at Stony Brook University. Each session included an array of activity-based learning techniques under the theme of “Marine Science during the Anthropocene”, with topics ranging from plastic pollution to local biodiversity impacts from climate change. This outreach workshop improved accessibility of science for diverse groups of students from three local high schools.
